cost.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the amount of money that you have to pay in order to buy, do, or produce something
cost.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: This doesn’t include the cost of repairing the damage.
The new building’s going up at a cost of $82 million.
Travel insurance is included at no extra cost.
The funds will just cover the museum’s running costs.
I offered to pay the cost of the taxi.
Insurance to cover the cost of a funeral is possible.
cost.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In everyday English, people usually ask how much did it cost? or how much was it? rather than using the noun cost:
cost.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: something that you lose, give away, damage etc in order to achieve something
cost.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: He’s determined to win, whatever the cost (=no matter how much work, money, risk etc is needed).
We must avoid a scandal at all costs (=whatever happens).
They need to weigh up the costs and benefits (=disadvantages and advantages) of regulation.
She had kept her promise to Christine, but at what cost to herself?
cost.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: the price that someone pays for something that they are going to sell
cost.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: His uncle’s a car dealer and let him buy the car at cost  (=without making a profit).
cost.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: I’m not sure how I’m going to pay the cost of going to college.
The money he had saved just covered the cost of the trip.
His family were unable to meet the cost of his operation.
We can’t afford the cost of a holiday abroad this year.
If you go later in the year, it will bring down the cost of your holiday.
The government has promised to cut the cost of medical care.
The new tax will increase the cost of owning a car.
The cost of electricity has risen again.
What’s the average cost of a wedding in the UK?
At the campsite, many activities are available at no extra cost.
Experts are still assessing the full cost of the disaster.
The estimated cost was in the region of £3,000.
This figure represents the annual cost of a loan.
They had to pay £30,000 in legal costs.
The new technology is cheaper and the running costs are lower.
Interest rates and borrowing costs are likely to be higher next year.
People are complaining about the rising cost of living.
cost.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: the amount of money you need to buy or do something. Cost is usually used when talking in a general way about whether something is expensive or cheap rather than when talking about exact prices
The cost of running a car is increasing.
the cost of raw materials
price
the amount of money you must pay for something that is for sale
They sell good-quality clothes at reasonable prices.
the price of a plane ticket to New York
value
the amount of money that something is worth
A new kitchen can increase the value of your home.
charge
the amount that you have to pay for a service or to use something
Hotel guests may use the gym for a small charge.
bank charges
fee
the amount you have to pay to enter a place or join a group, or for the services of a professional person such as a lawyer or a doctor
There is no entrance fee.
The membership fee is £125 a year.
legal fees
fare
the amount you have to pay to travel somewhere by bus, plane, train etc
I didn’t even have enough money for my bus fare.
fare increases
rent
the amount you have to pay to live in or use a place that you do not own
The rent on his apartment is $800 a month.
rate
a charge that is set according to a standard scale
Most TV stations offer special rates to local advertisers.
toll
the amount you have to pay to travel on some roads or bridges
You have to pay tolls on many French motorways.
cost.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: A full day’s activities will cost you £45.
His proposals could cost the taxpayer around £8 billion a year.
How much would it cost us to replace?
Lighting can change the look of a room and needn’t cost the earth (=have a price which is too high).
Getting that insured is going to cost you an arm and a leg (=have a very high price).
It won’t cost you a penny for the first six months.
It’s costing us a fortune in phone bills.
What a fantastic dress. It must have cost a bomb!
cost.translation[1].definitions[0].note_: Cost is a linking verb that links the subject of the sentence with a noun, often an amount
A second-hand car doesn’t cost much
cost.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to calculate the total price of something or decide how much the price of something should be
cost.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: We’ll get the plan costed before presenting it to the board.
cost.translation[1].definitions[1].note_: Cost is often passive in this meaning
cost.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: Their hair products are really good but they cost a lot.
Second hand clothes don’t cost much.
There’s a one-day course that costs £80 per person.
The meal will cost about £20 per head.
Using the Internet, you can make phone calls that don’t cost a penny.
If you use a lawyer, it will cost you a fortune.
He has a new sports car that must have cost a bomb.
cost an arm and a leg
A skiing holiday needn’t cost you an arm and a leg.
cost.translation[1].note_box[1].sections: to have a particular price
The book costs $25.
A new kitchen will cost you a lot of money.
It’s a nice dress and it didn’t cost much.
be
to cost a particular amount of money
These shoes were only £5.
be priced at something
to have a particular price – used when giving the exact price that a shop or company charges for something
Tickets are priced at $20 for adults and $10 for kids.
retail at something
to be sold in shops at a particular price – used especially in business
The scissors retail at £1.99 in department stores.
sell/go for something
used for saying what people usually pay for something
Houses in this area sell for around £200,000.
fetch
used for saying what people pay for something, especially at a public sale
The painting fetched over $8,000 at auction.
A sports car built for Mussolini is expected to fetch nearly £1 million at auction.
set somebody back something
to cost someone a lot of money
A good set of speakers will set you back around £150.
come to
if a bill comes to a particular amount, it adds up to that amount
The bill came to £100 between four of us.
cost.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: the amount of money that you have to pay in order to buy, do, or produce something
cost.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The distributor bears the full cost of promoting a film.
Siemens is moving production to low cost sites in Portugal and Mexico.
The policy covers all major illnesses and includes children’s cover at no extra cost.
The company had to bring in skilled workers from abroad, often at high cost.
cost.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: the money that a business or an individual must regularly spend
cost.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: The rising costs of land and labour have weakened the ship repair business in Singapore.
Delays in construction could increase costs significantly.
Kraft is seeking to cut costs by closing plants.
Rents will be sufficient to cover costs (=pay for costs) and allow the developer a profit.
cost.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: How much did the work cost you?
cost.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: to have a very high price
cost.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: The meal cost a small fortune, but it was well worth it.
What a fantastic dress. It must have cost a bomb!
cost.translation[3].definitions[2].defin: to calculate the cost of something or decide how much something should cost
cost.translation[3].definitions[2].examp: We’ll get the plan costed before sending it to the board.
